channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iraqi Forces Enter Falluja, Encountering Little Fight From ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqi forces gathered in the center of Falluja on Friday, when they raised the national flag over a main government building.
item.description: Counterterrorism forces raised the Iraqi flag over the city’s main government building, according to officers and reports on state television.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: John Kerry Is Said to Side With Diplomats’ Critical Memo on Syria
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry arriving in Copenhagen on Thursday.
item.description: Administration officials say the secretary of state has been urging President Obama to put pressure on the Assad government to abide by a cease-fire and agree to a transition of power.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Saudi Imam, 2 Hijackers and Lingering 9/11 Mystery
item.media:description: Khalid al-Mihdhar at Dulles International Airport near Washington on Sept. 11, 2001. Mr. Mihdhar is one of two 9/11 hijackers who American investigators say may have been aided by a Saudi official.
item.description: To some, a classified section of an inquiry into the terrorist attacks points to Saudi involvement, while the country’s foreign minister says, “There is no there there.”
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Britain Asks if Tone of ‘Brexit’ Campaign Made Violence Inevitable
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, released a new poster for the campaign for Britain to leave the European Union on Thursday.
item.description: The killing of Jo Cox, a politician in favor of remaining in the European Union, has put a focus on the anti-immigrant tactics some in the “Leave” campaign have employed.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Choosing ‘Brexit’ Could Leave the Kingdom Less United
item.media:description: An abandoned customs post on Ireland’s side of the border with Northern Ireland. This frontier could become a lot more visible if Britain votes next week to leave the European Union while Ireland remains.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A vote by Britain to leave the European Union could create pressure for Scottish independence and harden the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Regardless of ‘Brexit’ Vote, Experts Say, E.U. Must Rethink Status Quo
item.media:description: A Union Jack fluttering beside European Union flags at union headquarters in Brussels.
item.description: Tribulations for the euro, a debt standoff with Greece and a flawed approach to migration all inflamed the angry nationalism spreading across the Continent and Britain.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: China’s Last Wild River Carries Conflicting Environmental Hopes
item.media:description: The Nu River at Bingzhongluo, China. Over the years, various government agencies and state companies have proposed building dams along the 1,700-mile river and harnessing its power.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: With global temperatures rising, can a nation afford to protect a pristine waterway and forgo the building of dams as an alternative to burning coal?
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: 194 Held in Bangladesh Mass Arrests May Have Militant Ties, Police Say
item.media:description: Activists in Dhaka, Bangladesh, held portraits on Wednesday of people who were among those killed in recent years in attacks claimed by Islamist militants.
item.description: The police came under sharp criticism from human rights activists for arresting more than 11,000 people in response to a campaign of killings by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: 11 Sentenced to Life for Muslim Killings During Gujarat Riots in India
item.description: The men were convicted of participating in a mob that set fire to a housing complex where scores of Muslims were taking refuge, killing 69 people inside.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Belgian Police Detain 12 in Anti-Terror Raids
item.description: A statement from federal prosecutors on Saturday suggested that an aggressive effort was underway to prevent the next extremist attack.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Suspect in British Lawmaker’s Killing: ‘My Name Is Death to Traitors’
item.media:description: A court artist sketch of Thomas Mair, the suspect in the killing of Jo Cox, a member of Parliament. Mr. Mair appeared in court on Saturday.
item.description: Thomas Mair, 52, who has been charged with murdering Jo Cox, a member of Parliament, made the remark during a brief court appearance Saturday.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Police in Brazil Seek Charges Against 7 in Gang Rape of Girl
item.description: The assault attracted international attention after videos showing men posing with the unconscious victim were shared on social media.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Thomas Mair, Suspected in the Jo Cox Killing, Is Charged With Murder
item.description: The shooting and stabbing death of Ms. Cox, a member of Parliament, has stunned Britain ahead of a vote on whether to stay in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Palestinians Enter Talks With Egypt to Stake Mediterranean Claims
item.media:description: Riyad H. Mansour, the Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations, in 2014. He says Palestinians are entitled to declare an undersea “exclusive economic zone” in the Mediterranean.
item.description: A Palestinian envoy said the negotiations were possible because of the Palestinian territories’ United Nations status as a nonmember observer state.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Premier of Ukraine Urges Europe Not to Ease Russia Sanctions
item.media:description: Soldiers from the First Mechanized Battalion, 14th Mechanized Brigade of the Ukrainian Army in February at a front-line position in Marinka, Ukraine.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: Remarks by Prime Minister Volodymyr B. Groysman came as European officials appeared to make an effort to temper the worst estrangement in relations with Russia since the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Olympic Ban Adds to Russia’s Culture of Grievances
item.description: The decision added support for a narrative that revolves around perceived slights and anti-Russian conspiracies taking place in the outside world.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Costly Compromises Stir Fury With the European Union
item.media:description: Outside the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France. There is a duplicate Parliament building in Belgium – one hint, critics say, of the European Union’s inability to make decisions.
item.description: Many Britons want to stop paying for an unwieldy club often hobbled by a lack of consensus.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Trilobites: 12,000 Years Ago, Humans and Climate Change Made a Deadly Team
item.media:description: An illustration from the 19th century of a giant ground sloth, which was among the many megafaunal species that went extinct in Patagonia during a rapid warming phase that followed the Antarctic Cold Reversal. Researchers found that the combination of human encroachment with the warming contributed to the extinctions.
item.description: By dating bones and teeth from megafauna found in South America, researchers found that prehistoric extinctions were tied to warming and the presence of humans.
item.dc:creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG

item.title: Apple iPhone Is Targeted in Beijing Patent Case
item.media:description: A couple look at an iPhone 6 at an Apple store in Beijing.
item.description: A complaint from an obscure Chinese phone maker resulted in a partial iPhone sales ban, though the order has been stayed as Apple appeals.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Syrian Baby Born With Deformities Gets Spanish O.K. to Come for Surgery
item.description: Sham Aldaher, who was born in Jordan in July, has been offered treatment in Barcelona, but her family struggled to get a visa.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Says It Won’t Take E.U. Money for Refugees
item.media:description: A migrant family sat on train tracks outside their tent in a refugee camp in Idomeni, Greece, in March. Tens of thousands of migrants are stranded in such camps in Greece.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: One of Europe’s biggest charities said Friday it is turning its back on millions of dollars to protest the bloc’s “shameful deterrence policies” on migrants.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: 3 Others Detained in China Over Liquor Commemorating Tiananmen Killings
item.media:description: A man stood before a line of tanks near Tiananmen Square in Beijing in June 1989. Liquor bottles with labels riffing on that protest began circulating on WeChat in May.
item.description: The bottles bore the image of a lone man blocking a line of tanks, a reference to an iconic figure of resistance to the deadly 1989 military crackdown.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Publisher in Exile Gets the Big Scoops on China’s Elite
item.media:description: Ho Pin, who runs a Chinese-language publishing company, in Queens in February. Living in the United States is his strategy for staying out of the clutches of China’s police if his publications offend the Communist Party.
item.media:credit: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times
item.description: While a crackdown stifles other freewheeling publishers, Ho Pin offers uncensored coverage from his Long Island office, beyond Beijing’s reach.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A Front-Row Seat to Germany’s Long Reckoning With Its Past
item.media:description: Leon Schwarzbaum, a Holocaust survivor who was at Mr. Hanning’s trial on Friday.
item.description: After the sentencing of Reinhold Hanning, who may be the last former Nazi sentenced for war crimes, reflections on how Germany has addressed its history.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Bookseller’s Account of Abduction Rekindles Fear of Lost Rights in Hong Kong
item.description: The detention of Lam Wing-kee on the mainland has many worried that harsh Chinese justice, or lawlessness, is seeping into the city.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: EgyptAir 804 Flight Data Recorder Is Found, Egyptian Investigators Say
item.description: The announcement came one day after they said they had found the cockpit voice recorder of the doomed plane, which crashed on May 19.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: 2 Chinese Activists Sentenced to Over 10 Years on Subversion Charges
item.media:description: People last year protesting the detention of Chinese activists who support Hong Kong’s Umbrella Movement, including Lu Gengsong and Chen Shuqing, in Hong Kong.
item.description: Lu Gengsong and Chen Shuqing were convicted for publishing pro-democracy essays on overseas websites and promoting the banned China Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Thomas Mair, Suspect in Jo Cox Killing, Is Investigated for Possible Neo-Nazi Ties
item.media:description: Police officers searched near where Ms. Cox was shot a day earlier in Birtsall, England, on Friday.
item.description: The police said they believed that Mr. Mair had targeted Ms. Cox, a member of Parliament from the Labour Party, for political reasons.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sinosphere: American Kills Himself in Taiwan Court After 4-Year Drug Sentence
item.description: The man, Tyrel Martin Marhanka, convicted of growing marijuana for personal use, slashed his throat with scissors at his sentencing, court officials said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: In Race for Mayor of Rome, a Prize and a New Face for the Five Star Movement
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, a lawyer and municipal councilor in Rome. She appears poised to become Rome’s mayor in a runoff election on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Born as a voice of anti-establishment protest in Italy, the movement is poised to win the city’s mayoral runoff on Sunday behind Virginia Raggi, a relative newcomer.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Shifting Attention to Mediterranean, NATO Fights Internal Dissent
item.media:description: British paratroopers jumped from a C-130 Hercules plane during an alliance training exercise near Torun, Poland, this month.
item.description: Beyond confronting Russia in the east, the alliance is facing an array of challenges on its southern flank, including terrorism and uncontrolled migration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Christo’s Newest Project: Walking on Water
item.media:description: A new installation by the artist Christo, “The Floating Piers,” consists of temporary bridges spanning Italy’s Lake Iseo.
item.description: For 16 days, “The Floating Piers,” a saffron-colored walkway, will connect two small islands in a lake in Northern Italy to the mainland.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Leaving Past Behind, Northern Ireland Unified Behind Its Team
item.media:description: Northern Ireland fans applauded their team after Sunday’s loss in the European Championships.
item.description: A boy who watched the biggest soccer match in his country’s history in 1982 is now the coach. He hopes to replicate the team’s success in the European Championships.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE

item.title: What in the World: A Magnet for Titanic Fans in an Unexpected Graveyard
item.media:description: The Fairview Lawn Cemetery in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on April 15, 2012, the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic.
item.description: Fairview Lawn Cemetery holds more victims of the world’s best-known shipwreck than any other place — including the grave of a certain J. Dawson.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Rise at 11? China’s Single Time Zone Means Keeping Odd Hours
item.description: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. in Urumqi, where clocks are set to Beijing time despite being 2,000 miles to the west.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: The Deeper Meaning of Mexico’s Giant Speed Bumps
item.media:description: A well-worn tope in Mexico City, scarred by the undercarriages of countless cars.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Suspension-killing wonders called topes, which crop up on highways and back streets alike, are a means of enforcing speed control and civility, and cannot be avoided.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Opinion: Drought Selfies and Drought Suicides
item.media:description: A boy from a rural village stricken by drought standing guard over his family’s water containers at a camp in Mumbai.
item.description: India's government cares little for the plight of the rural poor.
item.dc:creator: SONIA FALEIRO

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte: After Orlando
item.description: Donald Trump is assiduous about word choice.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Mr. Modi, Don't Patent Cow Urine
item.description: India’s innovative patent system has brought cheap generic drugs to millions. Now it’s under threat — because the Hindu right is obsessed with cows.
item.dc:creator: ACHAL PRABHALA and SUDHIR KRISHNASWAMY

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
